title: Joe Kennedy III enters U.S. Senate race against Ed Markey
content:
Joseph Kennedy III launched his U.S. Senate bid Saturday morning in the basement gymnasium of the East Boston Social Centers , paying homage to his family ’ s immigrant roots in the neighborhood while pledging to “ show up ” for Massachusetts as he embarks on what promises to be a marquee contest against incumbent Edward Markey .
“ This community , Massachusetts , has been with my family for an awfully long time . You have stood by us in good times , and through some tough times , ” Kennedy said . “ And so my commitment to you , throughout this campaign , if I am fortunate to serve in the United States Senate , is that I will show up . ”
Kennedy , a U.S. Representative , seeks to reclaim his family ’ s Senate mantle by unseating Markey — entering a race that also includes labor attorney Shannon Liss-Riordan and business executive Steve Pemberton .
Not to be outshone , Markey — who joined protesters at Friday ’ s climate strike on City Hall Plaza — released a video Saturday calling on his opponents to participate in a climate debate in November . Pemberton readily agreed and called for monthly debates on myriad issues .
Kennedy launched his Senate bid with a roughly 10-minute speech outlining his ancestors ’ pursuit of the American dream and how he wants to help others achieve it in the face of a fractured society riddled with roadblocks he says helped propel President Trump to office .
“ We have a president that is actively trying to make that harder . We have a Senate that instead of trying to harness the opportunity and potential of every person in this country , they ’ re trying to pull us back , ” Kennedy said . “ I ’ m running for the United States Senate to tear that down , to fight back . ”
The challenges facing the nation are “ far too urgent to sit there and wait for somebody else to take it on , ” Kennedy said .
Kennedy told reporters he ’ s focusing his campaign on fighting for affordable housing , accessible health care and “ economic justice , ” and on beating Trump and flipping the Senate .
He bucked against the notion his primary challenge would fracture the party and drain its financial resources .
“ I just don ’ t think that ’ s the case , ” Kennedy said . “ Running an energetic , engaged race across the entire state to bring more voices into the democratic process is somehow anti-democratic ? There ’ s just no logic to that argument . ”
The latest member of the storied political dynasty to serve in Congress , Kennedy , 38 , brings his family pedigree and youth to the contest . Markey , 73 , touts four decades in Congress and co-sponsorship of the Green New Deal with progressive firebrand U.S. Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez .
Kennedy sought to draw differences with Markey that stretch beyond generational , saying the race is about “ vision , leadership , energy. ” He said he rejects corporate PAC money — “ Senator Markey has not ” — and supports abolishing the electoral college and enacting term limits for the Supreme Court .
“ Senator Markey is a good man . It ’ s going to be a tough race , and I look forward to making my case , ” Kennedy said .
Attendee Rita Lara lauded Kennedy ’ s choice to launch his bid in East Boston and draw on his immigrant roots as a “ source of strength . ”
Teresa Aravena called it “ strategic ” for Kennedy to get “ more Latino people to look at him . ”
As Kennedy highlighted his family ’ s journey , Markey at last week ’ s state Democratic convention emphasized his working-class upbringing in Malden and his father ’ s childhood among the Lawrence mills .
Markey was absent from the campaign trail Saturday due to a friend ’ s funeral . But his lead campaign strategist , John Walsh , told reporters , “ I believe in competition . I believe in winning competitions , and I ’ ve got the best candidate . ”
Walsh seemed undeterred by the weight of a Kennedy challenge — early polls showed the representative leading the incumbent senator by a wide margin — citing endorsements from Ocasio-Cortez and U.S. Sen. Elizabeth Warren .
“ Competition is good for our party . It ’ s good for our country , ” Walsh said . “ And this contest , if we have the courage as Massachusetts Democrats to honor the students who struck yesterday by putting climate change first in this debate , whatever happens here we ’ re going to elevate these issues . ”
Kennedy ’ s kickoff — with supporters and family including his father , former Congressman Joseph Kennedy II , his two young children and his wife , who was celebrating her birthday — was followed by a seven-stop tour around the state . He ’ ll continue with another six stops throughout Sunday and Monday . His campaign also released endorsements from Teamsters Local 25 and the mayors of Salem and Newton .
